sp.p: Upon my life, Sir, there's not a Syllable but bears this Conſtruction, which perfectly agrees with all other Circumſtances.—And now, Sir, to give you the Soul and Quintiſence of my Embaſſy, which was whiſper'd to me by your Miſtreſſes Confident, and no doubt by her order, you are ſuddenly to meet her.—Prepare your ſelf for a Rencounter,—ſhe is accidentally to fall into the Ambuſh, and you are to bear her off with flying Colours.—Come along, Sir, I'll ſhew you the place,—the time draws near.

div.stage: Strike ſure, for 'tis the Criſis of your Bliſs.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'll ſtrike at Fate, ſhould I the Bleſſing miſs.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: SCENE Covent-Garden.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Purflew and Mrs. Plyant,

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: SHall we go look upon ſome Silks, Couz?—Coll. Bellair lodges ſomewhere hereabouts; ſhou'd he meet us, he'd conclude I came on purpoſe to ſee for him.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Good lack! and not judge amiſs;—as if you did not know that I ſent him word we ſhould be here, with Reſolutions, as I imagin'd, to conclude on the matter, when to crown his Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I know you ſent him word!—I conclude the matter! I crown his Paſſion! What does the Girl mean?

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! This is very pritty;—I am ſure you gave me large hints to gueſs at your Intentions.—And pray what's the buſineſs of an humble Confident; if not to inch out coming Inclinations, or bear the blame of pretended Miſtakes.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I can't imagine what you'd be at.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Lord, we Women in love are ſo perverſe in our Humours,—and would always ſeem to walk counter to our Intentions; what advances we make are backwards, like the Marches of a Crab.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I own I have let the Woman grow a little upon me:—I have nettled him, I believe, in the Letter I ſent by Jocond; though I left him room for a favourable Interpretation, but Lovers generally lay hold on the wrong end.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: How many of us do make Pride and Ill-nature our Diverſion? We love that our Tongues ſhould contradict our Hearts; as well as to have our Women belye our Faces,—and are always ſtretching our Thoughts for new Matter to torment both our ſelves and our Lovers.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Well, ſay what you will, I am reſolv'd, when I ſee him, to receive him very coldly.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: And I am reſolv'd to diſabuſe him.—I am confident you love him, and doubt not in the leaſt his Sincerity, why then ſhou'd you ſacrifice the Repoſe of him you eſteem at the coſt of your own?

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I am ſure I have reaſon to ſcruple his Sincerity; ſince I very much believe he gives himſelf the ſame licentious freedom in the World as ever.

sp.speaker: Ply
sp.p: Why? you would not be ſo unreaſonable to expect to be ſole Proprietor, before you are in poſſeſſion, would you?

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Beſides, there's a ſecret pleaſure to ſee how our Admirers behave themſelves under a diſgrace: who would not know the force of her Frowns, as well as the power of her Smiles?—A little inſult is an inſeparable Prerogative of our Sovereignty during our Courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: And we often pay dear for playing the Tyrant,—when a Man of Sence comes to reflect on the baſeneſs of his Slavery we deſign him, and prudently refuſes the weight of our Shackles, how contemptible do we appear when we proſtrate our Charms afreſh to re-invite his Service;—therefore, Couſin, have a care of playing foul in Love, leaſt you loſe your Gameſter that has the beſt Stock and then be oblig'd to play with others upon Tick.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I proteſt yonder he comes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This, Madam, was the kindeſt thing imaginable;—and though you are fair to a Miracle, it may bring in queſtion, whether your Goodneſs is not of larger extent than your Beauty.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Perhaps, Sir, you miſ-interpret the One, as you miſtake the Other.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Sufferings have confirm'd my Judgment;—and had I ten thouſand Lives, the force of your Charms would be juſtify'd by as many Victims.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I am convinc'd you are in no great danger of being ſacrific'd to the force of Love; you're not unexperienc'd of a ſure way of Prevention.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: None but your ſelf can cure the Wounds you have made.—Nature generally provides the ſureſt Antidote from what caus'd the Infection.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: And from the firſt Principle of Nature, I ſhall take care of Self-preſervation.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'T would be Sacrilege in the higheſt degree to injure her chiefeſt Work.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: But, Sir, tho you were ſo Improvident to entertain an unlucky Paſſion, —I am confident your long abſence has by this time procur'd you a good reaſonable Indifferency.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Abſence, Madam, has had the ſame effect on my Paſſion, as the Wind has on Fire;—it extinguiſhes a faint Flame, but feeds and excites a great one.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: And has not your She-volunteer had Power ſufficient to abate thoſe Flames?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What She-volunteer?—Hang me if I can imagine what you mean!

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Come, what little bickrings are theſe betwixt you two Lovers?

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Do you know this Hand?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, by my Soul don't I.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: How's this!—but I do:—Lord, was this the buſineſs that rais'd your mighty Scruples?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: [to Plyant] I beſeech you, Madam, the meaning on't?

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: That Letter was a Contrivance of your old Aunt Whim's,—ſhe made Mrs. Grace Copy it, and then ſent her with it, to her Brother at the Poſt-Office, to put it in amongſt the Foreign Letters.—Let me ſee, it begins thus;—You would do well, Madam, to entertain no farther thoughts of that dear Man, whoſe Fatigues I ſhare, and whoſe Careſſes I enjoy, and ſo forth:—by the ſame token the Night you receiv'd it, ſhe laid the Blaid-bone of a Shoulder of Mutton under your Pillow, and pump'd you the next day at Dinner for your Dream.—Do you remember this?

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: And you, Couſin, privy to the Contrivance?

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Indeed Mrs. Grace ſhew'd me the Letter;—but I profeſs I look'd upon it ſo frivolous and improbable, that I never minded to acquaint you with it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Madam, you ſo eaſily entertain thoughts to my prejudice.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: However, Sir, ſince it does not lie in my power.—

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Nay, now I ſwear you tell a Ripper;—for to let you know the truth,—it never did lie in her power till this very day; and now ſhe is wholly Miſtreſs of her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now, Madam, where lies tho next Objection?

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Well, ſince as my Couſin Plyant tells you, I am but this day ſole diſpoſer of my Perſon, it's but reaſonable I ſhould ſpend ſome time under my own Juriſdiction.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Faith my Service ſhould not diminiſh but enlarge your Dominion.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I have no mind to be ſerious now, but will give my Thoughts a looſe for the preſent. Adieu—Come away Couſ.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Whatever Circumference they take, ne're doubt, Sir, their centring upon you,—Hark you, we'll be anon upon the Walks.—Adieu, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hey-day,—what can be the meaning of this? If ſhe gets once into the Town-road of Love, I had been much happier to have receiv'd the kind Salutation of a Twelve-pounder long e're now.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: This is only a feint to draw you to Battle.—Well, of a Souldier, I never ſaw ſuch a timorous whining Lover as you are.—Why did not you take the little Baggage and fling her into a Coach, and away with her, I'm confident you'd pleaſe her better than to have her repent her bargain.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sirrah, hold your prophane Tongue, or I'll cut it out;—what you ſay, I cou'd do, did I not love her;—nay more, cut any bodie's Throat that interpos'd:—Raviſh the Joys ſhe were ſo nice of, and then abandon her to Deſpair and Infamy.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Ay, now you talk like a Man of your own Profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Such an Action might be the reſult of Luſt; or what were due to a Jilt; but mine's a Flame pure as the veſtal Fire, and ſhe as ſacred as the pious Saint that attends the Altar:—But this I'll do, I'll purſue her to the utmoſt, and reach her too if poſſible.—Numberleſs are the Toils of Love and War, and whoever expects to ſucceed in either is requir'd to be indefatigable.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Juſt upon the ſtroak of Three;—the Alderman, no doubt, will be here preſently; here he comes already.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Oh, art thou there, my truſty Mercury?

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I find, Sir, you are punctual to a minute.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: 'Sbud, I am as hot as a pamper'd Prelate,—my Blood beat an alarum in my Veins to give me notice of the time, and away I came, I'dad.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I'll ſecure you as cool as Clouted Cream e're ſhe has done with you; I'll aſſure you ſhe's almoſt inacceſſible, had not I the influence of a Relation over her.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Prithee ſee, ſee, good boy; 'Sbodlikins I took a Doſe of Cantharides this morning, and methinks I am ſo luſty.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I vow you look as brisk, Mr. Alderman, as though you were but fifteen.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: I? Hem—hem—There's Lungs for you—I am as ſound as Heart of Oak, boy:—I was a pritty Youth when I was fifteen—nay, I am a very comely handſome old Gentleman now.—Old—not very old neither, a little turn'd my Prime, not much neither—But prithee ſee, ſee a little whether ſhe be at leiſure, my dear Boy, will you?

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Here ſhe comes—Madam, a very worthy acquaintance of mine begs the liberty to kiſs your fair Hand.

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.p: I am oblig'd, Sir, to give civil Entertainment to your ſelf; or to any friend of yours, ſo far as it conſiſts with my honour.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: When you hear me knock, take care to ſlip him into your Cloſet.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Madam, as the riſing Sun is ador'd by the proſtrate Perſian, no leſs Worſhip and Veneration ſhall be paid you, by your humble Slave and Vaſſal Nicholas Whim, Citizen and Alderman of London.

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.p: Vou are very Courtly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Nay hold, you ſhall have more—Nor has the Rays of your bright Eyes diffus'd their Power with leſs force, through the Territories of my Heart, than does the Beams of that glorious Planet ſhed their Influence through the utmoſt depths of our ſublunary World. Hem, hem. This I heard a City-Poet ſay to my Lady Mayreſs.

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.p: What makes you ſo florid, Sir? you might ſpare your Rhetorick—a more familiar way of Expreſſion ſuits better with the matter of Love; and I ſuppoſe that's your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Yes, my ſweet Sugar-ſops—Love, Love's the dear buſineſs—You have hit the mark, you have nick'd it I'dad—and I'll nick you anon—and my Name is Nick—and there will be Nick upon Nick: how do you like that, Lady Bright?—was not that ſmart and familiar?

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.p: You are a very merry Gentleman, truly.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Piſh, this is nothing, my little Pigſny, to what you ſhall ſee me do anon —To give you a taſte of my familiarity, let me mumble, let me mumble theſe Pitty-paddy-pods of yours, E-e-e-e—now let me ſmuggle between my little Biddy's Bubbies, E-e-e-e—Oh how did they caper it, ferk it and jerk it under the green-wood Tree. [Sings and Dances.] O Lawd, O Lawd, I am taken with a ſtrange Dizzineſs in my Head—Pray, Madam, have you ever a Coach, or a Pallat-bed, where I might repoſe my ſelf a little.

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.p: Sir, I'll conduct you into my Chamber, and give you ſome of my Waters.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Thank you, good Lady; thank you, good Lady.—There, there was a Project of mine.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: So, there's one noos'd—I ſhan't be long without the Fellow on thee: To trap theſe old Buck-fitches, is, I think, a very reaſonable piece of Service.—It's ſo prepoſterous a thing to ſee old doating, drivelling Fellows pretend to feats of Love; the thoughts of it chills my blood, and gives me a diſrelliſh to the ſweet Sin it ſelf. I proteſt here comes Sir Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I am ſincerely glad to find you ſo minutely punctual, Mr. Eager.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir, I ſhould have been erroneous to a degree of ſtupidity to have diſappointed a Perſon of your Worth and Character; eſpecially in a buſineſs of this moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: You ſay well, Sir: It is a matter of great moment—Scowring off the Ruſt of Nature, and refining our Vital Spirits, from the ſcum and droſs they contract, by cohabiting with the Earthly particles of the Body—By which the Mind may become alleviated, and all its noble faculties operate with greater freedom and vigour.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I vow, Sir Nicholas, you talk very prittily of Wenching.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I underſtand it in all its Branches, Diviſions, and Sub-diviſions. —how far it has been encouraged in ſeveral of the beſt-conſtituted Governments —and how we came to be Prieſt-driver from the allow'd practice of it.—I have compos'd a little Tract upon that Subject, which I deſign to get Printed at Amſterdam—It will be of ſingular uſe.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: It's pitty but the World ſhould be oblig'd with it.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I have there laid down its Riſe, Growth and Progreſs, and have trac'd it from its very Original; which I find to be very Antient—Wonderfull antient, truly.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I proteſt, Sir, your Diſcourſe of it almoſt equals its pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: But, Mr. Eager, pray one word with you—Is this Lady of any Deſcent? —has ſhe any pretenſions to Coat-armour?—I vow I won'd not Contaminate my ſelf with vulgar Blood for Chriſtendom—I would not touch the Fleſh of any under a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir, ſhe is a near Relation of mine by my Mother's ſide, her Name Veſuvia.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Veſuvia! Ods ſo, of the Old Neopolitan Veſuvians—Let me ſee, ſhe beareth in a Field-Argent a Furnace Sable, ejecting ſulphureous Flames proper.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Her Furnace may have a Neopolitan Heat in it, as far as I know; do you look to that.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: A Family of great Antiquity, upon my Honour.—Burning of Brimſtone has been of very long dare in the World.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: And is like to continue very long, or elſe we lie under a great miſtake.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Sir, will you pleaſe to Supplicate the Lady to admit of my humble Devoirs.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: This is her Lodgings, I'll knock and ſee whether ſhe be at leiſure.
So now for my Diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Having, Madam, received Intimation of your Ladiſhips high Worth, and nobleneſs of Blood, I look upon my ſelf to be oblig'd in honour to tender you my Offers of diſplaying your bearing, and ſearching into your Pedigree.

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.p: What a pritty ingenious way you have found of opening your Intentions, Good Sir Nicholas Purflew.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: A Lady of tranſcendent Parts, I dare avow.

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.p: Your Character is ſo honourable, and your Ingenuity ſo conſpicuous, that I ſhall be proud of ſerving you—Within here, in my Chamber, I have my Scutcheon; if you pleaſe, you ſhall go in and ſee it.

div.stage: [A Noiſe of Roaring and Singing without.]

sp.speaker: [Bullies without.]
sp.p: Scour, ſcour, ſcour; Ferret, ferret the Whores; Bolt, bolt.

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.p: O Lord, what will become of us? ſome rude drunken fellows are got into the Houſe, ſlip into my Cloſet, and I'll deal with 'em as well as I can.

div.stage: [Veſuvia thruſts Sir Nich. into the Cloſet.
Enter Eager in Diſguiſe, with Bullies.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Here, here's one.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: O, Madam Mynx, are you there?—Where are the reſt of your Coneys of this Burrough?—Da—me, we muſt have every one, one, or you'll have very hot work on't.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: 'Sbud unrig her, uncaſe her; make the Picture of Fortune of her, and let her ſhew the Naked truth.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Let us Revel and Roar, the whole World is our Store;
Nay, the Gods ſhall Club to our Pleaſure:
When we Wallow all Night, in an unknown Delight,
Aurora diſcovers the Treaſure.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Let us never Repine, whilſt brisk Wenches and Wine,
Make the Brims of our Lives run over;
Leave the How and the What, to the Politick Sot,
And the When, to the Fool of a Lover.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Thus free from all Cares of Taxes and Wars,
We know not the Name of Dull Sorrow;
Ev'ry Purſe is our Prey, which we ſpend in a Day,
And the Devil take Care for to morrow.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: What, is the Brimſtone vaniſh'd?—I'll rummage her Cloſet for a Bottle of cold Tea.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Da—me, do, and we'll ſee the bottom of it.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Ro—t me ſo we will, and then ſtagger to freſh Game.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: 'Ounz here's a brace of old Fornicators.

sp.speaker: Bullies.
sp.p: Out with 'em, Out with 'em.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: No, one at a time.—What a pox does your Goatſhip here?

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Kimbaw him, Kimbaw him.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Ay, ay; Kimbaw him, Kimbaw him.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: We'll only make you lighter by a ſtone or two—that's all, get a cleft ſtick and a ſharp knife here.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: [In the Cloſet.] O—h.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Hold your bellowing, your turn's a coming.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Why look you, friend, I am a Man of honour—Sir Nicholas Purflew by name, Herald and Antiquary by profeſſion; Therefore out of a juſt reſpect to all honour either paſt, preſent, or what's to come; I hope you'll regard me with a due Decorum, and deſiſt from any rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Da—m your Decorum—You have been a Traytor to your own lawfull Spouſe, therefore you muſt be revers'd.

div.stage: The Bullies ſet him on his Head, and ſhake all the Money out of his Pockets, which Eager gathers up.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: Ay, ay; Reverſe him, reverſe him.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: It rains plentifully; this is one of Old Jupiter's ſhow'rs; ſo in with him: now for the next.

div.stage: [They turn him in, and the Alderman comes skipping out.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, do you ſee, Gentlemen, I love a Wench, Gentlemen, as well as the beſt of you, Gentlemen—and believe you are very honeſt Gentlemen; and make uſe of this project to get a little Ready—Pray take this Purſe I'dad, and I won't grudge you a Groat on't.

sp.speaker: Bull.
sp.p: A very reaſonable Gentleman.

div.stage: [Eager and the Bullies go off, ſhaking the Purſe, and Singing, Every Purſe is our Prey, which, &c. and crying, Scour, ſcour, ſcour.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Come Brother Sir Nicholas, the Coaſt is clear, a couple of very pritty fellows I'dad.—A—h, Brother, this comes of Whoring.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: O Lawd, O Lawd, I ſhan't get my Guts in their right place this month—And the fright for my Manhood won't off, I fear, much longer.—This muſt certainly be an enchanted Caſtle; thoſe three were Gyant's Cubs, and that Jezebel the Witch, I dare ſay ſhe had Cloven feet, had we look'd.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Let's make the beſt of a bad Market; pop into a Coach;—Drive to a Tavern, and drink away Sorrow.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I heard a great Noiſe, thought you might be abus'd; and coming to your Reſcue, was met in the next Room by ſome Ruffians, ſtript as you ſee, and beat moſt confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: I'dad I began to have but an ill opinion of thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs I began to have ſome Dubitation, that Mr. Eager had not dealt very candidly.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: This I get by being ſerviceable to my Friends—and now to be Ill thought on ſticks worſe by me than my Baſtinading.—Wrong my Friends?— I'de be drawn Piece-meal firſt.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Come Eager, we'll take thee along with us, and recompence thee for thy misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: That's the Houſe, Sir, where the two Ladies went in.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Very well, enough, enough:—Go bid my Coachman turn the Coach before the door, and laſh the Horſes,—and do you Dogs make a noiſe, that the Ladies may look out of their Windows and ſee the Splendour of my Equipage: —I would have the Eyes of a Whole ſtreet upon the Gaze, as ſoon as ever I approach it.—Lol, lol; la, ra, la, ra.

div.stage: Enter Sapleſs haſtily, Puffing and Blowing.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Oh, Couzin, ha I found you?

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: How now, Mr. Sapleſs,—how long have you been in Town?— What a pox makes you in ſuch a heat?

sp.speaker: Sapl.
sp.p: Why, I was going to ſee for yo, to know whether yo can oſ • e me, to find out our John't Baily; I ha been running up tawn and dawn tawn to finden, and one had as good look't Needle in Bottle a Hay, as any body in this tawn.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: What the devil does he ſay? Da'me if I underſtand him a ſyllable— How does my Lady and your pritty Siſters?—When do they come to town?

sp.speaker: Sapl.
sp.p: They'r aw weel at whome, thank ye.—T'laſſes are aw-ways tawking on you, Couzin—They lov'n you hugeny b'maſs.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Don't ſay Couzin, when you ſpeak to a Perſon of Quality, but ſay, Sir— and prithee try to ſpeak intelligibly; Lawd, lawd, what a monſter of a thing is a Country Squire—Oh ſaw, how he ſtinks of Sweat.

sp.speaker: Sapl.
sp.p: Giſs a little Snuſh.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Ounz how he paws it!—a foot of an Ox would take it out handſomer— 'Od confound him, he has dropt my box.—What the devil have you done, Sir?—there's not another box-full of it in the Univerſe—I had it from Donna Aurelia Formalitoſa, and ſhe had it from Don Antonio Erneſto Steffatito, and he had it out of the King of Spain's own Box.

sp.speaker: Sapl.
sp.p: A chawnce, a chawnce comes aws wee'l, aws wee'l:

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Pray, for the Reſpect I bear your Family, let me furniſh you with a Tutor, that he may cut you out of the Rough, and Poliſh you a little;—and when you have got your Engliſh, and know how to put on your Cloaths, you may be fit to go to the Accademy—Then I'll take care to lay on the finiſhing ſtroaks, and make a compleat Gentleman of you.

sp.speaker: Sapl.
sp.p: Yo tawken—'Sfleſh I am a Gentleman enough aw-ready in mine none Country, and I thinken I ought to be thoughten ſo here; for I ha been faw drunk at Tavern, and have layn all Neet at a Bawdy-houſe; and they tell'n me yo London Geutlemen do no more.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: O abominable! I find thou art beyond the hope of Retrieving.—I' gad here comes the Ladies—away Sapleſs—vaniſh, prithee vaniſh, I would not be ſeen in the Company of ſuch an Animal for the Univerſe.

sp.speaker: Sapl.
sp.p: Marry, and yo been thereabouts—I had rather be Coupled to our Joler for a twelve month, than be forc'd to ſtay with yo for an hour: and ſo fare you well with a Murrain to you.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Powder me, Powder me, ye Dog.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Purflew and Mrs. Plyant.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: O Ladies, I ſeize you here as lawfull Prize—I rule in this Pariſh of Covent-Garden as Sovereignly by day, as ever Stoaks did by night, and the Beauties of theſe Precincts conteſt my power with as little ſucceſs as the Bullies did his.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Sure Sir, the limits of a Pariſh are two ſmall to confine your Graces— the Rays of your Charms have an influence that's Univerſal.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: That's true, Madam; and when ever they contract themſelves to give place to a greater Light, it is in your Preſence.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Right Mr. Gooſandelo ſtill.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Indeed there's little danger of Mr. Gooſandelo altering his temper—a harden'd Fop is as irreclaimable as a ſottiſh Drunkard.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: But, Madam, I ſuppoſe you are not unacquainted with Sir Nicholas's Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I don't at all diſpute his Intention, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Nor ſcruple his Judgment, I hope.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: There was little occaſion for its being over-diſcerning in its Choice of you, Mr. Gooſandelo.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: That's true again, Madam.—I vow I pitty ſome Ladies that I know— this Wedding will mortifie 'em ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: No doubt of it.—Come, Couzin, let's away.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: I'll Uſher you to your Coach, Ladies.

div.l: Drive on Dull Time, to reach my Waiting Joys,
Moments are Ages in a Lover's Eyes.
div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: SCENE Walks.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: THeſe are the Walks—But I ſee nothing of them yet.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Ne'er doubt their being here anon, Sir.—I queſtion not but ſhe is as intent upon the Matter as your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sirrah, hunt about, and be as vigilant as a Lynx—You ſhall meet with me hereabouts.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: I'll ſecure you, Sir, my part ſhan't be wanting—I'll ſay that for my ſelf, there is ne'er a Puppy-dog in the Kingdom better taught to ſeek out and find, than I am.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: For my life I can't find out the true nature of Woman—not a ſingle motion of their Minds, but ſeems irregular—their Thoughts and Reſolves no ſooner bubble up, but they break and are diſſipated with the ſame puff of Air, that firſt rais'd 'em—the Compoſure of their Souls is too light and unſuitable for the ſtrength of their Charms; which have power to oppreſs with a delight, and to enſlave with a pleaſure, whilſt with a ſecret Joy, we loſe our ſelves, and blindly trace the mazing Labarinths of Love.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: 'Tis no otherwſe than I expected—'Sbud, Sir, you look very charming— with this Preſence you have power to kill like Lightning at a diſtance— 'Tis but clapping your Hat before your face, and taking it away again of a ſudden— Flaſh, if ere a Woman in Chriſtendom would not fall as flat as a Flounder, I'd periſh.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: May be ſo, I now—Ha bien ajuſté; let me die, Eager, I think thou do'ſt not flatter me.

div.stage: [Looking in his Glaſs, and pruning himſelf.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Flatter you!—You can't be flatter'd, your Perfections are unſpeakable.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: I have now put on moſt of my Graces, in order to the celebrating my Nuptials.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Why, the Bride can't chooſe but think ſhe has got a Young God in her Arms.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Gad I am a Violent Fool to make Love to Mortals, paultry fleſh and blood—I ſhould reſerve my ſelf for Nymphs and Goddeſſes.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: No doubt they'll come in ſearch of you; if you'll have but patience— Was you ne'er attack't with a Succubus yet?

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Succubus, ſuccubus, who's ſhe? Some forreign Princeſs! is it not?

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p:
No Sir, no; they are black-ey'd Ladies of the Royal Blood of Pluto—
when they find a Man that's caſt in ſomething more than Humane Mould, you appear to be; they ſlip gently into his Bed when he's faſt a-ſleep,—claſp▪ their airy Limbs about him, and ſo enjoy him in a Dream.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Pox on 'em, if thoſe are they I have 'em ev'ry Night;—they haraſs me off my Legs.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: They are very buſie when they find out ſuch a compleat, ſweet, youthful Perſon as your ſelf, eſpecially if he's a Lover of Provocatives, ſuch as Shellfiſh, Cavere, Eringo-roots, Piſtachoo-paſt, Spaniſh Chocolate, &c.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: There's the buſineſs then, for I violently love all ſuch things;—but, Eager, there's a great bulky Volume of the Law, a Favourite of the Alderman's, hankers after my Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I know him, Breviat: Dam him, next time you ſee him in your Miſtreſſes Company, kick him, he dares not fight:—To my knowledge he's as fraid of a drawn Sword as an Atheiſt is of Thunder.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Wou'd I were ſure of that,—not but that I know it impoſſible for any Man to ſupplant my Intereſt in her; but I wou'd not have her blow'd upon by the breath of ſuch a Bear, and I am ſo paſſionate, that I proteſt I dare ſcarce truſt my ſelf with repairing my own Injuries:—Can'ſt not get him murther'd for me?

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: It will be ſomething chargeable if you'll have it done decently.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Decently? No, no, butcher him any how, his foul Carcaſs does not deſerve a jauntee thruſt, elſe I'd do it my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Firſt do you beat him, if he mutters I'll take him to task.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Let me die, Jack Eager, thou'rt a very honeſt fellow;—prithee accept of this, and ſtand my Friend; [gives him Money.] thou ſhalt ſtay with me:—If he comes, you and I and my Footmen will trounce him, I'gad,—we'll ſacrifice him, a Dog, a Rogue, a Son of a Whore.—

—O Lord, here he comes,—don't take any notice of it, for I ben't in a quarrelling temper at preſent.—Your Servant, good Mr. Breviat,—I muſt own I never had any eſteem for a Man of your Profeſſion till your Worth laid an Embargo on me and my Services.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, trade freely with your Services where you pleaſe;—I fear your Stock is ſo low, that you are not able to fraight for a Paſſage, were it only to croſs Covent-Garden, to give an account how your Complection heightens.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: What, do you intend to be ſharp upon me?—if you do, look to your ſelf, for I'll • ſerk you with Repartee, I'll promiſe you.—Eager, this is the Gentleman that's like to carry the great Fortune, Mrs. Purflew.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: 'Twill be impoſſible if you make Pretenſions, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I proteſt every moment, you make freſh Diſcoveries of your Sence and Judgment.—Let me periſh if I han't forgot to be put on my Scented Leather-Shooes.—Gentlemen, a matter of high concern requires my attending upon my ſelf to my own Apartment.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a Fop in Nature?—and yet they tell me, that the Ladies dote on ſuch Fools.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: That the Ladies love Fools is true enough, but they muſt be Harmleſs, Credulous, Paſſive Fools, not ſuch a Self-admiring Fool, as Mr. Gooſandelo is, that inſiſts ſo much on the Theme of his dear ſelf, that he can't afford the fair Sex their ſhare of Worſhip and Flattery.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: That I believe is very true.

div.stage: Enter Sapleſs and Veſuvia; Sapleſs making awkard Love apart.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Then a Country Eldeſt Brother Fool, goes down very well with a Lady, though ſhe be a Woman of good Sence, ſuch as there's a pattern of [pointing to Sapleſs] and ſhe will very lovingly take into her Arms his Worſhip's lump of animated Earth, though the Blockhead's Brains were compos'd of the worſt Mud about his Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: But ſtill I apprehend ſome danger from this Coxcomb Gooſandelo.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: When you ſee him in your Miſtreſſes Company affront him;—Pull him by the Noſe; all Women hate a Coward, as much as they do the Man that deals ſincerely with their Looks or Conduct;—and I am confident he dare not reſent it.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Are you ſure of it?

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: As ſure as that a London Juſtice go's ſnacks with Pick-pockets, or that his Clerk gathers Contribution round the Whores Quarters.—Your Man of Dreſs is ever too nice for a Quarrel,—he has juſt now own'd that he fears you'll take occaſion to fall out with him.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: 'Sbud, I'll do't then. But he has been▪ at Paris, and has learnt how to puſh Mathematically, and kill by Demonſtration.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: If he comes to puſhing, let me alone with him. I'gad I am as ready at whipping Men through the Lungs as a Smithfield Cook is at ſpitting of Pigs at a Bartholomew Fair.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Stick to me, honeſt Eager, in this Buſineſs, and there's a token of Encouragement for you.—I muſt ſtep to a Gentleman's Chamber, I'll be here again in a moment.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Well, noble Squire, hey for Cheſhire, how proceed you with the Lady, ha?

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Marry, Maiſter Eager, we fadgen prattily:—I ha faſt hold on her, and I con but keep her:—But they ſen in our Country, that he that has holt on a young Woman has got a ſlippery Eel by the Tail.

div.stage: Sapleſs holding Veſuvia by the Skirts of her Gown.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Spear her then, Squire, and that will ſecure her.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: 'Sfleſh, and ſo I wood, on I cou'd but lighten on her on a Sond-bed:—Nea, what ſen yo, Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.p: I ſay, it's very hard for a poor weak Woman to withſtand your ſtrong and preſſing Importunities.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Do you think you can diſpenſe with a Country-life, Madam?

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.p: No doubt I ſhall be happy with my pritty Squire in any place.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Oh, we han huge merry Folks in Cheſhire!—I'ſe mind my Horſes and my Dogs, and yo ſan take care o'th' Dairy and feeding o'th' Swine;— and then at Night to Bed, to play at high Gaffer hoop, old Laſs.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Come, make no bones on't, there's a Spiritual Fleſh-broker lives hard by, that will mould you both up into one Maſs of Fleſh and Blood in a trice.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Maſs I'ſe lead her thither then. [Hawls her by the Tail, and Sings.] Come away, come away; ſweet if thou lov'ſt, come away.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: Coll. Bellair, you are come to the Concluſion of a merry Bargain: here's a Couple juſt going to be Prieſt-link'd;—you ſhall ſee Madam Veſuvia the Honourable Lady Sapleſs in a little while.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay?—Are you the Son of Sir Thomas Sapleſs of Cheſhire, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Yea, b'Maſs, I am his Son and Heir too, as God wou'd hea it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Father, Sir, was an honeſt Gentleman, and a very good Friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: So he was of mine, Sir, to die in good time and leave me the Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: So,—here's all at an end, I fear;—we ſhall have that impertinent miſchievous thing call'd Honour, ſpoil this buſineſs, I'faith.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I vow, Madam, I muſt do that piece of Juſtice to my old Friend, to put a ſtop to this Affair;—I can't in Honour do otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: I thought ſo, I'ſaith,—'tis time for me to be gone, leſt for the ſake of his old Friend, he ſhould think fit to break my Bones out of a point of Honour too.

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.p: Pray what do you mean, good Mr. Collonel? do you think with your Flams to make a breach betwixt our true Conjugal Love and Affection?—Don't believe a word he ſays, Squire.—Sir, you have nothing to do with Mr. Sapleſs,—he is my lawful Husband already; he has promis'd me, and that's enough;—and I'll have him if all the Law in the Kingdom will get him me, that I will, ye Scarlet Scarecrow, ye tool of Death and Deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold your noiſe, for 'tis to no purpoſe:—Mr. Sapleſs, you were upon the brink of Ruine, and going to marry a Doll Common, therefore come along with me,—I'll make you ſenſible of the piece of ſervice I do you,— and for this time put you into ſecure Hands.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Marry, and may be yo tel'n me nothing but what's truth, and therefore, as they ſen in our Country, Two words a bargain, I'll look before I leap, ſo I will.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come away, Sir, pray come along with me.

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.p: What? do you think to run away with my Husband? I'll have him; I tell you, I'll have have him in ſpight of you,—ye paultry, filthy Upſtart you.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Purflew and mrs. Plyant.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: It's pleaſant being abroad this Evening.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: I am glad it draws ſo near Night, I would willingly be Femme Covert under the luſty Lawyer:—Here he comes, I vow; I find he has follow'd us upon the dry ſcent.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: What are you upon the hunt for, Spark?—Some Vizor-Mask to put Law-Caſes to.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: I am come, Madam, to retrieve a purloin'd Heart,—I have iſſu'd out a Writ de Corde Replegiendo, and it is return'd Elongat' by your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: You make very learned Love, this might take with ſome old Weſtminſter-Hall Trotter.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: I had rather referr my Bus'neſs with you, Madam, to the Abby than to the Hall at preſent.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: That you mayn't be out of your Road, I'll entertain my Couſin here to put in my Plea.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: I fear I ſhall betray your Cauſe for ſelf-intereſt, as all Lawyers do;—I muſt plead guilty, and put in Security for reſtoring the loſt Heart, for which, Sir, I'll be bound body for body.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: I can't except againſt the Bail;—but if I had it under the Lady's Hand and Seal 'twere ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Purf▪
sp.p: What, would you be hooking me into Contract?—If you are ſo miſtruſtfull before-hand, I may well judge of your Jealouſie afterwards;—and ſo, Mr. Lawyer, you may turn over another leaf, for you'll find nothing to your purpoſe here, I'll promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: How's this? my Miſtreſs hot upon the Lawyer? I am glad to ſee that, I faith.—What now, Black-Box, with Broad-Seal of Yellow Wax?—for ſuch ſeems your Face afixt to your Body when your Gown's on: What receiving Reprimand at the Bar, ha?

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: What make you ask?—thou Compoſition of perſum'd Paſt work'd up by the Hands of Quack Operators, thou haſt nothing of thy own about thee, but thy Sence, that indeed ſeems thine by making ſo dull a forc'd Jeſt, and afterwards explaining it.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Do you think this is very becoming, Gentlemen, before us?

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: I apprehended this Lawyer had ſome-how diſoblig'd you, Madam, and ſo look'd upon my ſelf bound in honour to engage on your Ladiſhip's ſide.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: 'Sbud I'll venture to affront him.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I beſeech you, Sir, if you muſt engage, let it be for your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: My ſelf? ſo now I have a good ſubject, Madam, I am—

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, if you once begin to talk of your ſelf, we ſhall ne're ſtop your Mouth, therefore you ſhall hear me handle that Subject conciſely:—You are a vain, noiſy, empty, inſipid—

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Fool.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: How's this, Sir, is it manners thus to take the Fool out of a Lady's Mouth?

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: I think, Gentlemen, it would be Manners to ſhare your Diſcourſe ſo, that you might by turns entertain us both.—I han't had a ſyllable from either of you yet.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: That's becauſe this Body of the Law has interpos'd; I know my ſelf accompliſh'd with all the Rules of general Converſation, and have ſuitable Sayings for all Complections.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: I am no ſtranger, Sir, to your moſt refin'd way of Diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: You confound me, Madam, with your Encomium, tho I muſt own the juſtice of it: Now for you, Madam, [to Purf.] let us look fix'd on each other a while, that I may drink up your Eyes with mine;—and I that look ſo brillant with my own, how glorious ſhall I appear with the addition of your Rays?

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Still you take care to ſqueeze in your ſelf;—I believe you would ſuffer more patiently the loſs of your Miſtreſs,—than be depriv'd of that dear Self-Opinion;—and in my Conſcience you undergo more hazard of being jilted by your ſelf, than by the moſt ſubtle of our Sex.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: What, Madam, do you deſign to be ſevere upon me, but I have bethought my ſelf of a ſure way of overpowring you, [Clapping his Hat before his Face, and taking it away again of a ſudden:] Flaſh, flaſh, I'gad you're fix'd and transfix'd.—What, Lawyer, are you Thunder-ſtruck too?

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: What a pox can you mean by this Foppery and Impertinence?

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: Come, Couz. let us ſlip into another Walk, and leave the Blockheads to wrangle by themſelves.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: What was that you ſaid, Sir Foppery and Impertinence;—you lye Sir, Foppery in the Face of you, and Impertinence upon your back-ſide.

div.stage: [Hits him a ſlap in the Face, and a kick on the Breech.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir? Come on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: A Fool, Sir.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: The Lye and a Kick, Sir?

div.stage: They often draw their Swords part of the way out, and ſlip them up again by turns.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Impertinent Fop, Sir.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Ay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Then no more to be ſaid, Sir.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: Then no more to be ſaid neither, if that be all; and ſo farewell till I meet you next.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Fare you well too, if you be ſo huffiſh.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I was coming, Sir, with what haſte I was able, to prevent miſchief, but I find your Prudence has over-ballanc'd your Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: I'gad, Sir, we were very near it;—had I drawn an Inch farther, my Sword had been unſheath'd, and then by this time, this ſpot of Ground had been delug'd with a Crimſon Flood.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You keep the Field, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, the Enemy fled not being able to make Head againſt the terrour of my Puiſſance,—and e're he rallies again I'll purſue and perfect my Conqueſt.

div.stage: [Exit contrary way to Breviat. Enter Mrs. Purflew and Mrs. Plyant.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: What are become of the Combatants?—We ſaw the deſperate Action through the Hedge.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha, ha; they have taken different Routs, I ſuppoſe, to prevent meeting again, tho, as far as I ſee, they may do it ſafely at any time;—they are certainly acting a Farce, or they are the rankeſt Cowards upon the face of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: They are very much in earneſt, I'll aſſure you, Sir, and the Prize they conteſt for, no leſs a Stake than this Lady.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I fear it would be very hazardous for the Lady to truſt her Honour under either of their Protections.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I ſhall take care never to bring my Honour ſo far in queſtion to need a Champion for its Defence.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The moſt virtuous, Madam, may be ſubject to Detraction▪

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: And a publick Vindication ſeldom abates the Scandal,—Innocence is the ſureſt Guard and the beſt Defence againſt a Reproach.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now your hand is in, pray Madam, give your Reaſoning Faculty the liberty of determining what ought to be the recompence of an unſullied Faith, and how long a time is requir'd to be convinc'd of the reality of Pretenſions.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: 'Tis eaſily anſwer'd, Sir,—if that Faith reſpects a Reward, it ſeems to be too ſelfiſh, and therefore deſerves none;—and if thoſe Pretenſions grow faint, and weary, it's a ſign they were never real, and therefore ought not to be valu'd.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Perhaps, Sir, I can give you a more ſatiſfactory Anſwer;—hark ye, a word in your Ear.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: I vow, Couzin, the Air grows ſo very cool, it's time we ſhould be going, come away.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Adieu, Sir,—I know we ſhan't be long before we ſee you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Come in diſguiſe, bring a Parſon with me and Jocond Mask'd in a Woman's Habit, this exactly agrees with what the Boy ſaid:—Now methinks the ineffable Joys begin to appear in view, a ſudden 〈◊〉 ſhoots
through my Veins;—my Blood moves quick, and my Breaſt heaves high, as doubting their force to ſuſtain the approching Bliſs, my haſty Thoughts anticipate the flowing Pleaſures, and leave me all diſſolv'd with the power of Apprehenſion.

div.head: SCENE changes to a Room in the Alderman's and Sir Nich. Houſe.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Well, old truſty Trojan, is all things in order?—has the Canonical Black his proper Poſt of Darkneſs?—haſt giv'n my Niece the Cautionary Inſtructions, honeſt old dry Chops, ha?

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: Yes, an't pleaſe your Honour's Worſhip, all things are as they ſhould be, and God ſend the Lawyer be ſo, all will be well o're, I'gad—I ha ſhed many a Tear to think on my poor young Miſtreſs to Night, God love her, poor tender Chicken.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Never doubt her, old Sprightly:—I'dad, I'dad, I ſhall grow as mad as a March Hare to hear the young Huſſie ſqueak.—If I ſhould come Caterwawling into the Garrets to Night amongſt the Wenches, be ſure thou exerciſeſt thy retentive Faculty, doſt hear?

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: An't like your Worſhip, I was never given to twittle twattle.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Don't you babble then, but hold your Clack.

sp.speaker: Spright.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, I'll be as ſilent as a Mouſe in a Cheeſe.

sp.speaker: Aid.
sp.p: I hear ſome body a coming, I believe 'tis the Lawyer, I'll go ſee.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Is every thing in a decent poſture, to make an honourable Reception for that true Epitomy of Honour, my ſpruce Nephew that muſt be? Alderman Whim ſmoaks nothing of our Project, I'll vow thou merit'ſt Coat-Armour for thy Cunning and Secrecy:—What think'ſt of a Cat Couchant, ods-life thou ſhalt have one for thee and thy whole Poſterity.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Bleſs your Honour,— • eckins I am glad at Heart I can ſerve your Honour's Worſhip:—I warrant my young Miſtreſs, Lord ſave my Child, will feel the Cockles of her Heart leap, when ſhe has got that ſweet ſmockfac'd Gentleman in Bed with her.—I'll go ſee that all things be done in print to your Honour's liking.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Do ſo, honeſt Sprightly.—Here comes old Whim to vent ſome new-hatch'd Project, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: I have been conſidering of it, Brother,—and find, if the War holds, we muſt of neceſſity introduce Poligamy for the ſupply of Men.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: On my word, Brother, you ſay well—The Huns, Lombards, Goths and Vandals, had ne'er made ſo many Southern Incurſions, had they not had a plurality of Wives.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: You ſhall invent Additions of Honour for them that are moſt dextrons at Propagation, and add to their former Coats, Bulls, Goats, Stone-horſes, and Cock-ſparrows—I'dad as old as I am, I'll have for my ſhare half a ſcore at leaſt, and ſtrut about, my little Seraglio, the luſty predominant Alderman, Sultan, Whim.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: You do well to talk of a Seraglio, for were thoſe ten Wives to go looſe, the Neck of the beſt Town-Bull in the Country would not be able to ſupport your Horns.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: But hark ye Sir Nicholas, my dear Brother and worthy Knight—Let's conſider of diſpoſing of our Charge—I'dad if ſhe gets ſenſible of her own Power, ſhe'll perhaps bob us both in ſhort.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Your Advice, dear Brother, is of great Importance—Here I'll read you a Liſt of our Propoſals.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: And I'll give you my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Imprimis, My Lord Grimace promiſes us Court-preferment.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: He has not Intereſt there, not ſo much as to have a Stand-by from the Yeoman-Uſher.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Item, My Lord Supple ſays he'll make his Appearance for us in the Country at the next Elections.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: His Honour is ham-ſtring'd by bowing two ways at once, therefore his Cringes will be of no farther uſe. But here's the Company a coming, to morrow we'll ſettle this Matter, and dedicate this Night to Mirth.

div.stage: Enter at one Door Breviat, Gooſandelo, Sapleſs and Eager, at the other Plyant and Jacond Mask'd; ſoon after Purflew alſo Mask'd.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: Oh, you Heavens! what, the Ladies in Maſquerade!—had we known that, we would have been in Habits too.—I wou'd have been the Great Mogul, Brother of the Stars, and Son of the Sun, and have out-ſhin'd my Glorious Father himſelf:—The Lawyer ſhould have been Preſtor John of Aethiopia, Mr. Sapleſs, Garagantua; and honeſt Jack Eager, Pantagruel.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: It's no matter, the Ladies ſhall Unmask preſently.—Pray Place you ſelves, Fiddles: Strike up.

div.stage: [The Fiddles flouriſh. Enter Tipſtaff, and Conſtables.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Hey-day, what's here to do?—What, Sir Nicholas, is your Arcadian Paſtoral to be perform'd by Tipſtaves and Conſtables?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: By your leave, Gentlemen, our Bus'neſs is with one John Eager, alias Curryman: here's the Gentleman, ſeize him.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: What, what's the matter? what Proceſs have you againſt Mr. Eager?

sp.speaker: Tip.
sp.p: Only a Warrant, Sir, that Charges him with a few ſmall Forgeries, of Bonds, Wills, and Indentures; that's all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Eag.
sp.p: So now muſt I be clapt up betwixt a pair of Iron-Grates, and ſqueez'd dry, and then be turn'd looſe for new Exploits—That's the main bus'neſs I proteſt, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Away with him, away with him.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: I'dad I began to believe this Eager was a ſort of a Dangerous Spark.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: You wou'd not believe me, Brother; for my part, I ſaw it in his Eyes, and diſcover'd the Perfidy of his Soul through the Port-holes of his Body.—Now, now ſtand clear.

div.p: An Entertainment of Singing and Dancing by Sheppards and Satyrs; in the beginning of which, Sprightly ſlips off, Gooſandelo and Jocond at one Door, and Breviate and Plyant at the other, who ſoon after return again. At the latter End of the Dance, Bellair appears in Diſguiſe.

lg.head: A SONG, in Dialogue, Sung by Mr. Reading and Mrs. Hodgſon: Set by Mr. John Eccles.

lg.l: 1 COme, Thyrſis, come; let us our Voices try,
And Charm the Woods with Orphean Melody.
2 This is the Glorious Annual Night,
That firſt gave fair Corinna Light.
1 The Bright Corinna,
2 Divine Corinna.
1 Corinna, who has Joys in ſtore;
2 Corinna, whom all Eyes adore:
[Both.] Corinna, who, &c.
1 Come, let us of her Graces tell,
Charms that do Themſelves excell.
2 Let us ſofteſt Notes reherſe,
And Sing her Beauties in Immortal Verſe.
[Both.] Let us ſofteſt, &c.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: We'll all joyn in Chorus, and Eccho her Praiſe;
Pay our Vows to the Gods, to ſmile on her Days:
May ſhe ever be Gay, may ſhe ever be Young;
As our Harmony ſweet, and as ſoft as our Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Very well perform'd, the Interlude we'll have after Supper.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Brother, Brother; Pray what Spark is this that looks ſo big, and ſtruts about at this Rate?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: It may be he is dropt from the Sky, for I know nothing of him.

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: [Leading up Plyant to the Alderman and Sir Nicholas] Gentlemen, I have the Honour to be your Nephew, and humbly beg you will Approve the Choice your Niece has made.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Ay, Niece: Have you been too nimble for us? Come, Brother, ſince 'tis ſo, Mr. Breviat is an ingenious worthy Gentleman, let's wiſh 'em Joy.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Ounz, what's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: [Leading up Jocond.] Ah, ah, ah; Faith, Lawyer, you are a little beſide the Point: Gentlemen, your Beautifull Niece has deliver'd her fair Perſon to me.—Under therefore your benign Aſpect, we ſhall ſhine the two brighteſt Glories of this your Hemiſphere.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: What a pox is the matter now?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Brother; Mr. Gooſandelo is a Perſon of Honour and Quality; I think we ſhall do well to Congratulate the Match.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: [Leading up Mrs. Purflew.] Make room here, I lay claim to this Lady, who lately bore the Name of Purflew, and am ready to juſtifie my Title.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich. & Alderm.
sp.p: Bleſs us, who's this?

sp.speaker: Purflew
sp.p: [Diſcovering her ſelf.] I hope, Uncles, the different Meaſures in each of your Conducts will excuſe my Choice of this Gentleman, whom I have made my Husband.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Pray will you all Unmask, that theſe Riddles may be explain'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: [Diſcovering himſelf.] My Name is Bellair; it ſhall be my Care to ſet a true Value on the Bleſſing I have obtain'd.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Coll. Bellair!

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Who have you got, Mr. Breviat? [Plyant diſcovering her ſelf.] What, my Couzin Plyant!

sp.speaker: Brev.
sp.p: O Lord, what will become of me when I go the Circuit!—Faith I may now go and take a gentle Swing into the other Word, and ſo finiſh the Law upon my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ply.
sp.p: Don't deſpair, Sir; now I am yours, I may be allow'd to own my Affections for you, and ſince Cuſtom deprives our Sex of making Court where we like; when I was aſſur'd of my Couz Purflew's Pre-ingagement, I took this method, and ſhall, I hope, by my Duty, procure your Eſteem.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: [Jocand diſcovering himſelf.] Oh ye Powers above, I have Married a Boy here.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gooſ.
sp.p: And Ha, ha, ha, too:—I'gad I'm glad on't, it's a very pritty Boy by my Soul: come to my Arms, my dear little Ganymede.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Fine doings, I'dad.—Ah, Brother, we are well enough ſerv'd for being ſo diſtruſtfull of each other.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Since my Niece has diſpos'd of her ſelf—I am glad ſhe has made Choice of you, Sir:—I am not unacquainted with the Family of the Bellairs, and you, Collonel, have added freſh Lawrels to the Deeds of your worthy Anceſtors, and have maintain'd an indiſputable Character of a Man of Honour.—Come, let's have another Dance, and ſo in to the Collation.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Come, now to Supper.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then to that grand Regale of Bliſs, where famiſh'd Love may make an inſatiate Feaſt of Beauty.

sp.speaker: Purf.
sp.p: What ſhare, Sir, I have of it, is but a juſt Reward for your faithfull Paſſion

div.l: They're ſordid Flames, that Int'reſt do's impart;
Nothing but Love's a Purchaſe for a Heart.

div.head: EPILOGUE: Spoke by Miſs Howard, in Pages Habit.
div.l: I Find I'm forward in my Tender • ge,
And ſhew the Early Manhood of a Page.
I dare already for a Miſtreſs Tilt,
Bully a Bawd, and Kick a Bant'ring Jilt;
Can cheat at Cards, Slur, Strike, or Palm • Dye,
Break Windows too, with Mid-night Gallantry.
Thus being qualify'd, I need not fear,
To go abroad a Taring Volunteer,
And be a Captain by another Year.
Ladies, look to't, by that time I come back,
I ſhall have learnt to Manage an Attack;
I'll Court you then in Military Strain,
And, by my Dint of Conduct, Conqueſt gain:
But e'er I bid adieu, Faith I've a mind
To leave you ſome good Wiſhes here behind.
May Virgin ne'er her firſt Deſires baulk,
So fall to feeding upon Coals or Chaulk.
May never Wife any Occaſion miſs,
To wipe her Lips of Husband's nauſeous Kiſs.
May no Rich Widow e'er her Kindneſs ſmother,
Or ſpare to pay the Pains of Younger Brother.
May none of either Sex, e'er fail to find,
A Lover conſtant, or a Miſtreſs kind.

div.head: Advertiſements.
div.p: OROONOKO: A Tragedy. Written by Mr. Southern. Deliciae Muſicae, the Fourth Book: which compleats the Firſt Volume. Printed for H. Playford and B. Tooke.
